quotes: Sirleaf nominated Phillip A. Z. Banks, her former Minister of Justice and Chairman of the Law Reform Commission, to replace Johnson in August 2011.
Banks was confirmed by the Senate on 20 August 2011.
Forbes magazine named Sirleaf as the 51st most powerful woman in the world in 2006.
In 2010, Newsweek listed her as one of the ten best leaders in the world, while Time counted her among the top ten female leaders.
In November 2017, an investigation conducted by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalism cited Sirleaf among the list of politicians named in 'Paradise Papers' allegations.
During the West African Ebola outbreak between 2014 and 2016, the President of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, played a central role in managing the crisis.

In August 2014, Johnson Sirleaf declared a national state of emergency, implementing measures such as border closures, restrictions on movement, and quarantines in highly affected areas to contain the spread of the virus.

organizations.name: Ministry of Health
quotes: Domestically, her government pushed for the creation of a national incident management system to coordinate the response between the Ministry of Health, United Nations agencies, and non-governmental organizations.

organizations.name: United Nations
quotes: Domestically, her government pushed for the creation of a national incident management system to coordinate the response between the Ministry of Health, United Nations agencies, and non-governmental organizations.

organizations.name: Presidential Advisory Committee on Ebola
quotes: She also established the Presidential Advisory Committee on Ebola, tasked with overseeing strategic actions and ensuring coherence in the work of partners on the ground.

organizations.name: United States
quotes: She formally requested assistance from the United States, which facilitated the U.S. military intervention to build treatment centers and provide logistical support.

roles.title: President of Liberia
quotes: During the West African Ebola outbreak between 2014 and 2016, the President of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, played a central role in managing the crisis.
During the West African Ebola outbreak between 2014 and 2016, the President of Liberia, Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, played a central role in managing the crisis.
Liberia was one of the most affected countries, along with Sierra Leone and Guinea, recording thousands of cases and deaths.
Liberia was one of the most affected countries, along with Sierra Leone and Guinea, recording thousands of cases and deaths.
She formally requested assistance from the United States, which facilitated the U.S. military intervention to build treatment centers and provide logistical support.
